race.name: Mid South
race.tagline: Oklahoma's weather lottery with a $100K purse and a guaranteed Bobby hug.

vitals.date_specific: 2026: March 13-14 (Pro race Friday, Amateur race Saturday)
vitals.start_time:
Pro Race: Friday 1:00 PM (2026 new format)
Amateur Race: Saturday 6:00 AM
vitals.registration: Lottery system ('The Randomizer'). Opens October. Cost: ~$165 (100mi)
vitals.prize_purse: $100,000 (split equally between elite men and women)
vitals.aid_stations: Miles ~30, 60. Water, snacks, neutral support. Sparse but sufficient.
vitals.cutoff_time: None. Finish when you finish. Bobby hugs everyone.

climate.description: Early March brings 40-75°F swings, potential freezing rain, potential heat, potential wildfires
challenges: Weather unpredictability is THE defining feature
Red clay turns to peanut butter mud when wet

terrain.surface: 98-99% unpaved Oklahoma red clay (iron oxide). Hard-pack when dry = slick center tread tires work well. 'Peanut butter mud' when wet—wheels stop spinning. Not the chunky gravel of Unbound.
features: Surface quality depends entirely on weather

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Legendary status since 2006. Bobby Wintle culture, weather lottery is THE defining feature. Overall +9 for cultural significance and community.

biased_opinion.summary: The Mid South is what happens when someone builds a gravel race around unreasonable hospitality instead of unreasonable suffering. Bobby Wintle hugs every finisher. The DFL gets the biggest trophy. The community shows up like their lives depend on it. And the weather? The weather does whatever Oklahoma wants. When it's dry, you get a blazing-fast tactical race. When it's wet, you get an unrideable mud nightmare. Either way, you finish to live music, local beer, and a town that genuinely wants you there. This isn't the hardest gravel race. It's not the longest. But it might be the one with the biggest heart.
strengths: Bobby's finish-line hug for every single rider—legendary and authentic
The DFL celebration—Dead F*cking Last gets a steer skull and the loudest cheer
Community vibe—Stillwater genuinely embraces the event, not just tolerates it
Weather lottery makes every edition unique (for better or worse)
$100K prize purse brings the fastest field in early-season gravel
weaknesses: Lottery registration system means you can't just sign up when you want
Weather unpredictability—you could train for months and get wildfires (2025)
Sparse aid stations (miles 30, 60) mean self-sufficiency required
Travel logistics—OKC/Tulsa airports 1.5 hours away, rental car mandatory
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you're asking whether Mid South is 'worth it,' the answer depends on what you value. If you want predictable conditions and a hard number to chase, look elsewhere. If you want a race that feels like a reunion with people you haven't met yet, where the community actually gives a damn, and where finishing dead last is celebrated as loudly as winning—this is it. You'll either love the chaos or hate the unpredictability. But you won't forget it.

final_verdict.one_liner: The early-season gravel race with the biggest heart and the most unpredictable conditions.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you value community, celebration, and authentic hospitality over predictable racing conditions—yes, absolutely. If you need to know what you're getting into before you commit—maybe reconsider. The Mid South is chaos wrapped in a Bobby hug. Some years it's fast and perfect. Some years it's a mud disaster. Some years it gets cancelled by wildfires. But the people who come back year after year aren't coming for the course—they're coming for the experience. Show up ready for anything. Leave with stories.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want the prestige without the weather lottery: try Unbound (harder but more predictable). If you want tactical short-course racing without the mud risk: try Gravel Locos (Texas, also 100mi, drier climate). If you want community vibe with better logistics: try Belgian Waffle Ride (San Diego, also chaotic but easier to access).

logistics.airport: Oklahoma City (OKC) or Tulsa (TUL) - both ~1.5 hours to Stillwater
logistics.lodging_strategy: Book early (October when registration opens). Stillwater has limited lodging but more than you'd expect for a college town. Hampton Inn partnership. Camping options available downtown (including courthouse lawn). Expect $150-250/night for basic rooms. Volunteers get guaranteed 2027 registration as a perk.
logistics.food: College town pricing = cheap. Lots of options downtown. Post-race celebration has food trucks and local beer. Stock your own race nutrition—aid stations are sparse.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday before race. Downtown Stillwater. Expect lines but not Unbound chaos.
logistics.parking: Free parking available downtown. Easier than Unbound logistics.

history.founder: Bobby and Crystal Wintle (owners of District Bicycles, 712 South Main)
history.origin_story: Started in 2006 as 'Land Run 100' with 121 riders, 107 miles, 6,000+ ft elevation. Bobby discovered 'every direction two miles out of Stillwater we've got some of the best dirt roads on planet Earth.' Opened District Bicycles in Sept 2008. Renamed to 'The Mid South' in 2013. The finish-line hug tradition started year one—Bobby hugs every single finisher. 'I still need my Bobby Hug!' is a common refrain from returning riders who travel 1,000+ miles just for this race. The event grew explosively to 2,500+ today.
notable_moments: 2019: Fast, dry conditions encouraged tactical pack racing
2024: Record-fast edition with average speeds over 20mph for front groups
2025: Race cancelled due to catastrophic wildfires and hurricane-force winds
2025: Ted King and Chase Wark rode unsupported FKT attempts, raising $8K+ for wildfire relief
2026: New format splits pro race (Friday) from amateur race (Saturday) for safety
history.reputation: The unofficial U.S. gravel season opener. Known for Bobby's finish-line hugs, unpredictable weather, iconic red clay, and one of gravel's strongest community vibes. The DFL (Dead F*cking Last) rider gets a giant steer skull trophy and massive celebration.

course_description.character: Fast and tactical when dry. Unrideable mud slog when wet. The weather decides what race you're getting.

suffering_zones.label: First Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Aid station one. Decide if you're racing or surviving.

suffering_zones.label: The Grind Begins
suffering_zones.desc: Aid station two. 40 miles left. Mental game starts here.

suffering_zones.label: The Final Push
suffering_zones.desc: Last 15 miles. You can see the finish but your legs disagree.

course_description.signature_challenge: The weather lottery. You train for months but Oklahoma decides what race you're riding.

guide_variables.race_weather: Weather lottery: 40-75°F swings, potential freezing rain, heat, or wildfires
race_challenges: Red clay that becomes unrideable mud when wet
Tactical pack racing when conditions are dry

non_negotiables.requirement: Weather adaptation training for unpredictable conditions (cold, heat, wind)
non_negotiables.why: Mid South's weather lottery means you could face 40°F freezing rain or 75°F heat. Training in varied conditions prevents race-day shock.

non_negotiables.requirement: Red clay handling skills and mud preparation
non_negotiables.why: Oklahoma red clay becomes unrideable peanut butter mud when wet. Bike handling prevents crashes and energy waste when conditions turn.

non_negotiables.requirement: Wind exposure training on exposed ridgelines
non_negotiables.why: Mid South's exposed ridgelines amplify wind. Training in wind builds the strength and tactics needed for tactical pack racing.
Tests nutrition, pacing, and mental preparation for 100 miles. Skipping it means discovering problems on race day.

topics.weather: Training for unpredictable conditions—cold, heat, wind, mud
topics.tactics: Pack racing tactics, when to sit in, when to push on exposed sections
topics.fueling: Calories, hydration, timing for 100-mile tactical race
topics.mental: What to do when weather turns and conditions change mid-race
topics.execution: Why most athletes fail intervals and how to execute correctly
topics.recovery: The honest takes on recovery between sessions

logistics.explanation: When 2025's 60 mph winds and wildfires forced cancellation, Trix8806 had 'police knock on our camper door' for evacuation with 'campers already burnt to the ground.' The Thursday Denim Ride now draws more participants than early race editions, while Bobby Wintle personally hugs every finisher. Stillwater logistics depend on local hosting like the Kiddoo family welcoming teammates. As Trix8806 puts it: "After about an hour, we were able to follow emergency vehicles out. Campers were already burnt to the ground and fire on both sides of the road... The spot we were parked initially was all burnt up."

length.explanation: Joe Laverick went 'fully in no-man's land' after missing the river crossing split, describing how 'history showing the early move is usually the one that wins' creates decisive tactical windows. John Borstelmann's relentless pace meant 'the group was down to 12 by the halfway checkpoint.' The single track section with 15km remaining provides final race-defining splits. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As B3BH1T puts it: "First time at Mid South and also my first gravel century. Came in at under 8 hours. Can't wait to be back next year. Glad I helped some folks on the rolling hills with my speaker playing metal music."

technicality.explanation: The Cimarron River crossing requires positioning where 'some people thought it'd be faster to hop back on the bike mid-grass bank. They were wrong,' according to Joe Laverick. Mid-race features 'craters on the right hand side' that 'wouldn't just be a race over but it'd be a visit to the hospital.' Otherwise it's grinding red dirt through Cross Timbers rollers with minimal technical demands. Less technical than Dirty 30. As Richard Poole puts it: "It only took 2 revolutions of your wheels to build up enough clay to stop you dead in your tracks."

elevation.explanation: Starting at 899 feet and reaching 1,222 feet maximum creates '800+ of climbing' through Cross Timbers rollers rather than featured climbs. John Borstelmann describes 'careening over the red dirt prairie' through relentless undulations where 30 mph crosswinds and tactical positioning matter more than elevation gain through Oklahoma farmland. Less climbing than Iowa Wind and Rock.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 65°F and lows of 45°F, with a 37% chance of rain on any given day. Weather defines survival and tactics. The 2025 edition saw 60 mph winds and wildfires with Air Quality Index hitting 500+, while historical conditions create 'horror stories. Red mud deep enough for every letter of murder. Chains chewed. Derailleurs gargled and spat.' Rescue jeeps are prepositioned for mass extractions when Oklahoma's red clay becomes impassable. Among the most weather-friendly events, easier than Badlands.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 899 feet in Oklahoma farmland means altitude doesn't factor into race outcomes. Maximum elevation of 1,222 feet through Cross Timbers terrain keeps you in low-altitude rolling prairie where oxygen debt is irrelevant compared to wind, positioning, and red dirt survival. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The course crosses the Cimarron River twice including 'at mile 81... using the new highway bridge not yet open to vehicles' plus private Bovine Bypass double track access. College and Triple XXX roads deliver 'local favorites' through Postoak and Blackjack Oak forests where Joe Laverick describes 'dust everywhere, impossible to see' positioning battles.

prestige.explanation: Joe Laverick calls this 'the best bike race experience of my life' and 'the true spirit of gravel.' Bobby Wintle notes 'the pros have looked at Mid South as the season opener' with elite riders treating it as their litmus test. When a brass band marches through 1,200 riders and Bobby hugs every finisher past midnight, you've built gravel culture beyond racing.

race_quality.explanation: Three aid stations with Skratch nutrition create tactical decisions through the Cross Timbers. Bobby Wintle's route development delivers private land access and unopened bridge crossings while 'history showing the early move usually wins' creates decisive racing. Joe Laverick's Di2 'randomly dies in the last few kilometres' proves the course tests everything mechanical and tactical.

experience.explanation: Joe Laverick describes 'dust everywhere, impossible to see' with relentless positioning battles through red rutted Oklahoma dirt and 'countless contours' of Cross Timbers terrain. The finish delivers bear hugs from Bobby Wintle while the DFL party celebrates riders finishing 'around midnight.' This grinding red dirt odyssey defines visceral Oklahoma gravel racing through extreme conditions.

community.explanation: Bobby Wintle hugs every single finisher from elites to the DFL party past midnight—over 1,000 individual celebrations. When wildfires cancelled 2025, riders like Chase stayed for relief efforts instead of leaving town. Joe Laverick notes 'World Tour winner or first time rider, every person matters'—that mutual aid during crisis proves authentic community. As Pre-Race Activities puts it: "In addition to shakeout rides and the music fest, there are also myriad other meetups at the Mid South, including a very fun beer can release party on Thursday at the local brewery to a Sunday yoga se..."

field_depth.explanation: Elite riders treat this as the season opener with John Borstelmann's attacks dropping the field to 12 by halfway. Growth from 121 riders in the first edition to over 1,000 finishers shows competitive depth proven by decisive splits at river crossings and mile 89 single track that determine outcomes from front to back of the field. Elite-level competition, on par with Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Richard Poole puts it: "Nothing could have prepared me for these conditions except maybe having done this race 2 years prior when the same thing happened."

value.explanation: You get 100 miles through private land access and unopened infrastructure plus Bobby Wintle's personal finish hugs for every rider from elites to DFL party past midnight. The full brass band start, Thursday Denim Ride, Friday running events, and weekend-long celebration deliver massive value beyond racing through Oklahoma's gravel community experience.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $165. Stillwater college town economics favor riders with local connections like the Kiddoo family providing accommodations where guests get 'grilled salmon marinated to perfect sweetness.' Rural Oklahoma territory keeps costs reasonable compared to destination resort pricing, though the Dirt Tan Bike Club author stayed with hosts who 'treated us as kings of health-conscious countries.' More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

videos.title: MEGA MID SOUTH 2024 Grand Depart -  Full Film
videos.description:
On September 18th, 2024 around 150 people gathered in Stillwater OK to take on the 300 mile MEGA MID SOUTH route,  an ultra endurance version of the 100 mile race held in March. 
Only 34 people finished the route. This film tells a few of the stories that happened over those 4 days. 

The next MEGA grand depart happens Saturday November 1st 2025. Learn more at www.midsouthgravel.com

Film by Josh McCullock 
additional camera :  Colten Sikes and Bryan Couchman
Mega Mid South design by Bryan Couchman

videos.curation_reason: High-quality documentary film covering the challenging 300-mile ultra version with compelling race atmosphere.

videos.title: Mid South 100 Pre Ride - Full Film
videos.description:
Come along with Bobby Wintle, Mid South Race Director, and his band of merry gentleman as they attempt the first ride of the Mid South 2026 100 mile route. * This was filmed in 2025 for that event preparation. The 2025 event was cancelled due to wildfires, and so we're happy to bring this top notch route to you for 2026! 
The Mid South is a weekend endurance festival held the second weekend of March in Stillwater Oklahoma. Learn more at www.midsouthgravel.com


dir / edit Josh McCullock
camera Colten Sikes 
design Bryan Couchman
motion graphics Ryan Fuller

videos.title: Mega Mid South 2024 300 mile gravel race
videos.description:
This video is brought to you by Simple Cycling Nutrition — fuel made simple. Get yours today with free shipping at https://www.simplecyclingnutrition.com/

The Mega Mid South 2024 was a remarkable 300-mile gravel bikepacking route that commenced on September 18, 2024, in Stillwater, Oklahoma, at District Bicycles. This inaugural event was entirely self-supported, free to enter, and open to riders year-round. The route was designed to showcase the diverse landscapes of Oklahoma, incorporating elements from past Mid South race courses. Riders who completed the route during the grand départ earned guaranteed entry into the 2025 Mid South gravel race .
midsouthgravel.com

🗺️ Route Overview
Distance: Approximately 300 miles

Elevation Gain: Around 5,727 feet

Terrain: A mix of gravel roads, red dirt trails, and scenic rural landscapes

Starting/Ending Point: District Bicycles, Stillwater, OK

Resupply: Convenience stores available roughly every 50 miles

Route Guide: Detailed information and maps are available on Bikepacking.com

midsouthgravel.com


🏁 Inaugural Grand Départ
The grand départ in September 2024 saw riders embarking on the challenging route over a long weekend. While the event was not a race, it fostered a spirit of camaraderie and adventure among participants. Riders who completed the route during this period secured their spots for the 2025 Mid South gravel race .


🏆 Fastest Known Times (FKT)
The FKT for the Mega Mid South was set by Chase Wark with a time of 16 hours, 58 minutes, narrowly beating Ted King's time of 17 hours, 18 minutes. Both riders undertook the challenge to support the Stillwater community affected by wildfires, raising over $8,500 for local charities .


📅 2025 Event Details
Grand Départ: Scheduled for November 1, 2025, at 8:00 AM from District Bicycles

Route: The 2025 route will follow the same 300-mile loop as the inaugural year .

Participation: Open to all; riders can attempt the route at any time, but completing it during the grand départ offers the benefit of community support and camaraderie

videos.curation_reason: First-person race experience capturing the challenging conditions and real rider experience at the back of the pack.

quotes.text: Choice old bridges double track that we've absolutely never hit before we've never seen by bike rather be on no other bike super sick... 106.8 miles with definitely over 7,000 ft of climbing.

You're never more than 50 miles from Still Water, but it doesn't feel like that. It feels like a genuine adventure... it could be a really really challenging individual continuous effort with maybe a nap or two or you could make it a 5 to 7 day journey.

Nothing like a little hike bike in the morning... this freaking wind is killing me. It's in the 20s or so maybe they pushed start back to 9am so that was nice for the cold but depending on the day goes i may be finishing in the dark.
